text: i'm so silly oh i'm so silly hi everyone
spaghetti freddy here the internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of this new spoon album lucifer
on the
sofa one of the most consistent and no
bands are back spoon going
strong for almost 30 years at this point
this is spoon's 10th lp and what's on
the schedule this time around why it's
rock of course
wow wow it's been five years since the
band's last full-length lp hot thoughts
where they uh subtly incorporated some
experimental and dance elements into uh
their very indie rock style and by
comparison i found lucifer on the sofa
to be a lot more moody and old school
with a lot of notes of hard rock and
blues rock on this lp to the point where
i think spoon is flirting with a bit of
a rolling stones here and there maybe
some zz top take for example the slick
motorcycle bar rips and grooves on the
hardest cut or the grand anthemic piano
backed choruses on wild the opening cut
held is a semi psychedelic piece of
blues rock with these huge washes of
guitar it's actually a bill callahan
cover that spoon mostly does justice
sticking to the original blueprint of
the song very closely and mapping their
instrumentation over on to
what bill and his band offered cleanly
but i still think i enjoy bill's
original version a lot more you can't
really beat the man's authoritative
baritone especially when it comes to
this more spoken word vocal style
overall the sounds on this lp are more
tried and true than they are new but
spoon spoon feeds them to us in a way
that serves as a reminder of what made
them so good in the first place either
on spoons past records or in
rock music as a whole especially when
you pair these elements with tight
playing good songwriting raw production
a front man as charismatic as brit
daniel who still shouts and howls on
these songs like he's got bills to pay
for as long as i could remember spoon
has very much been defined by a back to
basics ethos and that takes on different
forms uh given what track we're
listening to the devil in mr jones for
example is just drenched in
these uh 90s singer-songwriter pop rock
tropes that would have ruled the radio
back then but still to this day they're
pulled off with an urgency that prevents
them on this recording from uh sounding
super nostalgic or dated there are some
other cuts here that sound as if they
could have landed on a spoon album from
the mid 2000s but maybe now with
punchier songcraft and more harmonious
instrumentation the track feels alright
for example which isn't exactly i turned
my camera on but the badass piano and
guitar riff snapped in with that crispy
ass drum beat is classic spoon to its
core the song on the radio 2 which is
also a perfect example of rock not
needing to be complicated to be good a
good tune driving rhythm section
expressive lead singer and a strong
burst of keys on the chorus is kind of
all you need plus brit's narrative
allusions to being attached to something
as classic as like the radio format as a
kid in his lyrics as cute now there are
some low points on the record in my
opinion they are more often the mellow
cuts of course i don't want the band to
write a one-dimensional record where
every song sounds the same i appreciate
that they're trying to change things up
like on my babe or astral jacket but
with these tracks spoon really fails to
bring a memorable or moving ballad along
with the toning down of the intensity
the latter of these two tracks just kind
of sounds like a corny idyllic acoustic
cut that would gently play over the
loudspeakers at a coffee shop however
the song satellite does reach a point of
grandiosity and lushness that is kind of
refreshing to hear spoon approach and
the title track is a very nuanced and
relaxed jam loaded with easy going drums
and soft electric piano keys dreamy
vocal effects and spoken word from brit
as well it's a sensation that you really
want to get lost in a bit of a sonic
dream state in a way i think mood wise
and aesthetically it's a good note to
drift off on on this lp it's almost a 2b
continued moment for the band especially
with brit
singing about these lingering remnants
and and memories of someone or something
that he's lost but yeah i mean overall
this was another very solid album from
spoon where more or less the band met
expectations put out some good songs
put out a couple of snoozers too with
spoon it's always direct it's always to
the point it's always a bit of a mix but
there's usually a lot more good than bad
and that's what we're
still
getting so yeah
spoon feeling a decent seven on this one
tran position have you given this record
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review

forever
